Fig. 1 Schematic illustration for the synthesis of Ni@C catalyst. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Catalytic performance of catalysts for hydrogenation of MA at (a) 80 °C and (b)200 °C. (c)(d)The selectivity of GBL and SAH over all catalysts. Reaction conditions: 200 °C,3MPa Hydrogen pressure,500 rpm,0.05 g of catalyst, 0.025 mol of MA, solvent: 40 mL1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8h. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Reusability of the Ni@C-350 catalyst for the hydrogenation of MA. Reaction conditions: 0.025mol MA, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, 0.05 g catalyst, 200 °C, 8h, 3MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Kinetic experiments for hydrogenation of MA. (a-e)The corresponding plots of -ln(1-XMA) and reaction time of different catalysts at different temperatures. (f)Arrhenius plots for conversion of MA over the different catalysts. Reaction conditions: Hydrogen pressure: 3 MPa, 500 rpm, 0.025 mol MA, 0.05 g Catalyst, solvent: 40 mL 1,4-dioxane. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Kinetic experiments for hydrogenation of SAH. (a-e)The corresponding plots of -ln(1-XSAH) and reaction time of different catalysts at different temperatures. (f)Arrhenius plots for conversion of SAH over the different catalysts. Reaction condition: Hydrogen pressure: 3 MPa, 500 rpm, 0.025 mol SAH, 0.05 g catalyst, solvent: 40 mL 1,4-dioxane. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a,b)TG-MS profile of catalyst precursor. (c) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and (d) pore size distribution curves of all samples. (e) Raman spectra of different catalysts. (f) X-ray diffraction(XRD) spectra of Ni@C-T catalyst, the standard XRD patterns of pure Ni and NiO are provided for comparison. Fig 6 Fig. 7 High-resolution in-situ XPS spectra of Ni 2p 3/2(a), C 1s (b) and O 1s (c) of Ni@C-T catalyst. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a-d) HRTEM images and SAED pattern of Ni@C-350; (e) HAADF-STEM images of Ni@C-350 and the corresponding elemental mapping for Ni, C, and O. Fig 8 Fig. 9 H2-TPD profiles of catalysts. Research Paper Ni@C nanocatalysts for the highly efficient hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to γ-butyrolactone Chengliang Wang Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Software Supervision Validation Visualization Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a b Yin Zhang Funding acquisition Supervision Validation b ⁎ Haitao Li Conceptualization Data curation Funding acquisition b ⁎ Feifan Zhang Visualization a b Jie Wang Data curation a b Wei Wei Methodology a b Yongxiang Zhao Funding acquisition b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China b Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China bEngineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University, Taiyuan 030006, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Core-shell Ni@C catalysts with a uniform grain size distribution were synthesised via a simple hydrothermal method followed by pyrolysis carbonisation, and their catalytic performance for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride (MA) was investigated herein. When the pyrolysis temperature was 350 °C, the resulting Ni@C catalyst (Ni@C-350) possessed abundant Ni/NiO heterostructures and a carbon surface layer. Among the analysed catalysts, Ni@C-350 demonstrated the lowest apparent activation energy for the hydrogenation of CC bonds (Ea = 34.3 KJ/mol) and CO bonds (Ea = 65.18 KJ/mol), yielding an MA conversion of 100 % and a γ-butyrolactone (GBL) selectivity of 99.89 % under mild reaction conditions (200 °C, 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, and 0.05 g catalyst). Furthermore, the Ni@C-350 catalyst exhibited high stability, with the yield of GBL above 95 % after five consecutive usage cycles. Ni@C-350 significantly outperformed other previously reported catalysts for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of MA. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrogenation γ-butyrolactone Ni-based catalyst core-shell structure Ni/NiO heterojunction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a key raw material employed in organic synthesis, γ-Butyrolactone (GBL) is used to produce various important compounds, such as 2-pyrrolidone, N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone (NVP) [1], and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), which are widely used in medicine, pesticides, cosmetics, dyes, and lithium-ion batteries [2–4]. Additionally, GBL is directly used as an electrolyte solvent in the lithium-ion battery industry to enhance the solubility and conductivity of bis (oxalate) borate [5,6]. Owing to the rapid development of the lithium-ion battery industry in recent years, the market demand for GBL has increased significantly. One of the synthetic methods for GBL is the Reppe method [7], wherein GBL is obtained using formaldehyde and acetylene as raw materials via condensation, hydrogenation, and dehydrogenation reactions. However, the Reppe method requires a long reaction procedure and toxic materials, such as acetylene and formaldehyde. Another method for GBL preparation is the Davy process [8], which uses maleic anhydride (MA) as a raw material, involving the monoesterification of MA, diesterification of maleate monomethyl ester, and hydrogenation of dimethyl maleate. The Davy process requires three reactors, expensive catalysts, and harsh reaction conditions. Furthermore, the main product of the Davy process was BDO, and the highest yield of GBL was lower than 15 %. Compared to the Reppe and Davy methods, the direct hydrogenation of MA is the most direct, environmentally benign, and economical approach to produce GBL [9]. As shown in Scheme 1 . Furthermore, MA can be prepared by the oxidation of petroleum based butane, coal based benzene, or bio-based 5-hydroxymethylfurfural or furfural. Rational design of effective catalysts with high activity and stability for the hydrogenation of MA is of great industrial significance for the biomass chemical industry replace traditional coal chemical and petrochemical industry. The catalysts for the hydrogenation of MA to GBL mainly include noble (Ru, Re, and Pd) [10–12] and non-noble (Ni and Cu) metals [13,14]. Owing to the high activity of noble metal catalysts, deep hydrogenation products, such as propanol, butanol, propionic acid, and other by-products, are produced. However, the large-scale application of noble metal catalysts is limited because of their scarcity and high cost. In contrast, Ni- and Cu-based catalysts have been extensively studied for the hydrogenation of MA because of their high catalytic activities and low costs. Compared with Cu-based catalysts mainly used for gas-phase hydrogenation, Ni-based catalysts, such as Raney Ni and Ni nanoparticles [15], have been widely used for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of MA. However, because the catalytic activity required for CO hydrogenolysis is higher than that for CC hydrogenation, the main product of the Ni-based catalysts is succinic anhydride (SAH) [16–18]. For the efficient production of GBL, various strategies have been employed to improve the activity and stability of the catalysts. First, a second component was introduced to form bimetallic catalysts, such as Pd-Sn [19,20] and Ru-Re [21], for improving the dispersion of metals and regulating the electronic structure. Second, Ni-based catalysts comprising reducible oxide carriers that can induce synergistic interactions of metal and oxygen vacancy, such as Ni/CeO2 [16,17], Ni/ZrO2 [22], and Ni/TiO2 [23], were employed to promote the CO hydrogenolysis activity. Additionally, the preparation methods were modulated to improve the dispersion of active components and enhance the interaction between metals and carriers [14,18]. Based on recent studies, the incomplete reduction of Ni species can result in the formation of Ni/NiO heterostructures on the catalyst surface, which can significantly improve the activity of the catalyst for CO bond hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis [24–26]. In this study, a series of Ni@C catalysts was synthesised via a hydrothermal method followed by pyrolysis carbonisation. By controlling the pyrolysis temperature, Ni/NiO heterojunction catalysts with layered carbon structures were obtained, and their catalytic performance for MA hydrogenation was investigated. The catalyst pyrolysed at 350 °C (Ni@C-350) exhibited significantly high activity in converting MA to SAH and further hydrogenolysis to GBL and demonstrated excellent stability and recyclability during the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All reagents were of analytical grade and used directly. Sucrose was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate, MA, and SAH were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 1,4-Dioxane was supplied by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Sample preparation The catalyst was synthesised based on a previous report [27], and the details of the synthesis are shown in Fig. 1 . First, 6.12 g of sucrose, 26.19 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and 7.45 g of citric acid were added to a solution containing 270 mL of ethanol and 90 mL of deionised water. The mixture was stirred continuously for 1 h at room temperature and transferred to a stainless-steel vessel lined with Teflon. The hydrothermal vessel was placed in a drying oven and heated at 200 °C for 20 h. After the temperature decreased to room temperature, the precipitates were washed three times with deionised water and dried in an oven for 10 h to obtain greyish-green powders as the catalyst precursor. The precursor was transferred to a tubular furnace and then heated to specified temperatures at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min under N2 atmosphere with a flow rate of 50 mL/min for 2 h. The resulting catalysts are denoted as Ni@C-T, where T represents the pyrolysis temperature. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The nickel content was analysed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Fisher iCAP 7400). The thermogravimetry (TG) analysis profile was measured on a Mettler TGA/DSC3+ system, and the weight change was recorded during the heating process from room temperature to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min under N2 atmosphere with a flow rate of 50 mL/min. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) from 2θ = 5° to 80°. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM; FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin) and field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM; Zeiss Sigma 300) were used to characterise the morphologies and microstructures of the catalysts. The specific surface area and pore structure properties were determined using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 system. Raman spectra were recorded using a LabRAM HR Evolution Raman spectrometer. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vertex 70v spectrometer equipped with a deuterated triglycine sulfate (DTGS) detector. H2-temperature-programmed-desorption (H2-TPD) profiles were obtained using a Micromeritics AutoChem-2950 chemisorption instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were collected under high vacuum (10−8 Pa) on a Thermo Fisher Scientific XPS system (ESCALAB 250 Xi) with an excitation source of Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.8 eV), a working voltage of 12.5 kV, a filament current of 16 mA, and signal accumulation of 5-10 cycles. The pass energy was 40 eV, and the step size was 0.1 eV. The sample chamber is first filled with a precursor powder and then pumped with nitrogen at a flow rate of 20 mL/min by simulating the pyrolysis atmosphere. Second, the sample was heated to a certain temperature and maintain for 30 min through programmed heating, then the valence state and composition changes of the elements on the catalyst were analyzed by scanning test. First, the standard carbon was tested and its binding energy was 284.6eV, and then the catalyst sample was replaced for testing. In this way, the C1S of the XPS test result only came from the sample itself. 2.4 Catalytic performance test The performances of the catalysts in MA hydrogenation were tested in an intermittent high-pressure reactor. The catalyst was activated by pyrolysis under an inert atmosphere and directly placed in the reaction solution for testing. The testing solution contains 40 mL of 1,4-dioxane solvent, 0.025 mol of reactants, and 0.05 g of catalysts. The solution was stirred at 500 rpm to eliminate the effects of internal and external diffusion (Fig. S1). Before the reaction, the vessel was first sealed and purged with N2 for five cycles to eliminate the air in the vessel. Thereafter, H2 was filled for five cycles to replace the residual N2 in the vessel and the fifth purged with H2 until the pressure reached 2 MPa, then the reactor is heated to 200 °C. At this point, the hydrogen pressure inside the reactor increases to 3 MPa. Then, the stirring switch is turned on and the reaction starts timing. The liquid products were analysed using a SHIMADZU 2010 gas chromatography (GC) system equipped with a flame ionisation detector (FID) and an HP-5 capillary column. The calculations involved in the experiment was performed according to the following formula: (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( 1 − m o l e s o f M A i n p r o d u c t T o t a l m o l e s o f M A l o a d e d ) × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = m o l e s o f p r o d u c t i ∑ m o l e s o f p r o d u c t × 100 % (3) C a r b o n b a l a n c e ( % ) = ∑ m o l e o f c a r b o n i n p r o d u c t i T o t a l m o l e s o f c a r b o n i n M A f e e d × 100 % (4) * T O F C = C = n i n i t i a l × c o n v . S A H m c a t × n ( N i s u r f a c e ) × t where ninitial represents the initial moles of the reactant; conv. represents the conversion of the reactants; mcat represents the the actual amount of catalyst used in the reaction; n(Nisurface) represents the number of Ni atoms per gram catalysts surface obtained from H2-TPD data: according to the desorption peak of Hβ, and Hγ. t denotes the reaction time. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance test for hydrogenation of MA During the catalytic reaction, MA is subjected to an initial CC hydrogenation to generate SAH, which then undergoes CO hydrogenolysis to form GBL [28]. To accurately compare the catalytic activities of each catalyst in terms of CC hydrogenation and CO hydrogenolysis, the MA hydrogenation properties were investigated under reaction conditions of 80 and 200 °C, respectively (Fig. 2 a and b). When the reaction temperature is 80 °C, only SAH is detected in the reaction mixture, indicating that only CC hydrogenation is involved under this condition. As shown in Fig. 2a, the conversion of MA gradually increases with increasing reaction time. When the pyrolysis temperature is raised from 300 to 650 °C, the conversion of MA first increases and then decreases. The Ni@C-350 catalyst exhibits 100 % conversion of MA at a reaction time of 180 min, while the MA conversions of Ni@C-300, Ni@C-450, Ni@C-550 and Ni@C-650 are 6.32 %, 64.28 %, 30.48 % and 9.21 % respectively at a reaction time of 240 min implying the high activity of Ni@C-350 catalyst for CC hydrogenation. Fig. 2(b), (c), and (d) illustrate the time-dependent changes in MA conversion, GBL selectivity, and SAH selectivity at a reaction temperature of 200 °C, respectively. Except for Ni@C-300, all the catalysts achieve complete MA conversion within 60 min. As the reaction time extends, the selectivity for SAH gradually decreases, whereas that for GBL increases. Moreover, SAH and GBL are the only products detected during the reaction, indicating that the CO bonds in the SAH molecules are gradually hydrogenolysed into GBL with a prolonged reaction time. With increasing pyrolysis temperature, the selectivity for GBL first increases and then decreases. At a reaction time of 180 min, the Ni@C-350 catalyst shows the highest GBL selectivity (96.95 %) compared to the other samples, indicating its highest CO hydrogenolytic activity. Further extending the reaction time to 480 min, the GBL selectivity of the Ni@C-350 catalyst slowly increased to 99.89 %, indicating that the hydrogenation of SAH to GBL reaction had almost reached equilibrium at a reaction time of 180 min. Table S2 presents a comparison of the catalytic performance of the noble- and non-noble-metal-based heterogeneous catalysts recently reported for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of MA. The Ni@C-350 catalyst exhibits high activity in CC hydrogenation and CO hydrogenolysis. The stability of the Ni@C-350 catalyst was investigated for five evaluation cycles. As shown in Fig. 3 , the MA conversion rate remains at 100 % even after five cycles. However, the GBL selectivity slightly decreases from 99.89 % in the first cycle to 95.24 % in the fifth cycle. Notably, no byproducts are detected throughout the process, and the carbon mass balance stabilises at approximately 98 %, indicating the excellent stability and reusability of the Ni@C-350 catalyst. To further compare the activities of various catalysts toward the CC hydrogenation and CO hydrogenolysis, MA and SAH were utilised as reaction substrates, and the kinetic behaviours of each catalyst for MA hydrogenation to SAH and SAH hydrogenation to GBL were investigated. The kinetic results are shown in Figs. 4 and 5 , and the conversion details are presented in Supporting information Fig. S2 and Fig. S3. There is a linear relationship between -ln(1-X) (where X represents the substrate conversion) and reaction time for each catalyst shows that the hydrogenation of MA to SAH and the hydrogenolysis of SAH to GBL are both first-order reactions [29,30]. The apparent reaction activation energies of CC and CO hydrogenation for each catalyst were calculated using the Arrhenius equation. The activation energies and reaction rate constants are listed in Table 1 and Table S2 respectively. As the pyrolysis temperature increases, the apparent activation energies of all catalysts for CC and CO hydrogenolysis initially decrease and then increase. Among the analysed catalysts, Ni@C-350 exhibits the lowest activation energies of 34.3 KJ/mol for CC hydrogenation and 65.2 KJ/mol for CO hydrogenolysis, indicating its superior activity in the liquid hydrogenation of MA to GBL compared to the other catalysts. 3.2 Characterization of samples The TG-MS analysis of the precursor provided insights into the precursor evolution during pyrolysis. As depicted in Fig. 6 (a), the precursor exhibits three distinct stages of weight loss as the pyrolysis temperature increases from 50 to 800 °C [31–33]. The initial weight loss (approximately 15.55 % below 203 °C) can be attributed to the elimination of physically adsorbed water and crystal water from the surface. Subsequently, in the temperature range from 203 to 350 °C, a second stage with a weight loss of approximately 47.09 % can be ascribed to the phase transition of the Ni complex precursor commencing at 300 °C and its rapid decomposition at 320 °C. These findings are consistent with Fig. 6(b), which illustrates the release of large amounts of CO and CH4 at this stage [34], accompanied by the production of a small amount of H2O, Combined with the XRD characterization below (Fig. 6f), the pyrolysis process at 300 ∼350 °C is an important stage for the formation of the catalytic active center. In this stage, the Ni complex rapidly decomposes and releases a large number of small molecular gases containing reducing gases. Along with this pyrolysis process, the the catalyst precursor evolve into Ni and NiO species, thus Ni and NiO coexist in the catalyst. The third-stage weight loss (approximately 6.38 %) occurs between 350 and 650 °C. As the pyrolysis temperature gradually increases, a slow weight loss is caused by further carbon loss and the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni. Low-temperature N2 adsorption and Raman spectroscopy were conducted to elucidate the structures of the catalysts, and the results are presented in Fig. 6(c,d) and 6(e) and Table 2 . Based on the IUPAC classification, all catalysts exhibit type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms and type H1 hysteresis loops, indicating the mesoporous structures of the catalysts, which may originate from the small-molecule gases generated during pyrolysis [35,36]. The pore size distribution was further analysed using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method. The pore size distribution is uniform, and all catalysts, except Ni@C-300, show a single pore size distribution peak in the range of 2.5-6.5 nm. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to estimate the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts. As listed in Table 2, as the pyrolysis temperature increases, the BET specific surface area initially increases and then decreases. Ni@C-300 exhibits the smallest BET specific surface area (12.5 m2/g) because of the incomplete decomposition of the precursor. Ni@C-350 exhibits the largest BET specific surface area (148.3 m2/g). As the pyrolysis temperature further increases, the BET specific surface area gradually decreases [37]. The pore size increases slightly owing to the thermal reduction of NiO in the catalyst. The Raman spectra in Fig. 6(e) reveal that the characteristic D-band (1350 cm−1) and G-band (1598 cm−1) of carbon materials are observed for all catalysts except for Ni@C-300. The D-to-G band intensity ratio (ID/IG) does not change with increasing pyrolysis temperature, indicating that all catalysts have similar degrees of graphitisation [38,39]. The absence of the D-band and G-band peaks in the Ni@C-300 spectrum (Fig. S4a) is probably because the precursor only undergoes an initial phase transition without forming any ordered or disordered carbon skeleton at 300 °C, which is consistent with the TG results. The XRD patterns of the catalysts are presented in Fig. S4b and Fig. 6(f). Fig. S4b shows the XRD patterns of the precursor and Ni@C-300. The characteristic peak at 2θ = 24.3° corresponds to the (002) crystal plane of carbon is detected for Ni@C-300, in addition, the peaks at approximately 2θ =37.3° and 43.4° can be classified as highly dispersed NiO species (111) and (200) crystal plane. However, the Ni@C-350 pattern exhibits characteristic peaks at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of the face-centred cubic (fcc) Ni (JCPDS. No.04-004-8492), respectively. Additionally, the peaks of the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of NiO (JCPDS. No.04-011-2340) are observed at 37.3°, 43.4°, and 62.9°, respectively [32–34]. These emerging diffraction peaks suggest the co-presence of Ni species (Ni and NiO) in the Ni@C-350 catalyst. With an increase in the pyrolysis temperature, the characteristic diffraction peaks of NiO gradually disappear, whereas those of metallic Ni gradually increase. The average Ni grain size was determined using Scherrer's formula based on the diffraction peak of the Ni (200) crystal plane [24], and the results are presented in Table 2. To understand the catalyst surface composition during the pyrolysis, in situ XPS was performed on the catalysts. The full spectra in Fig. S5 reveal the existence of Ni, C, and O. Fine Ni 2p, C 1s, and O 1s spectra were also collected. A 2p3/2 spin orbital is used to match the chemical states of Ni on the catalyst surface in the Ni 2p region (848-868 eV) [33,39]. The peaks at the binding energies of 856 and 852 eV are related to the NiO (Ni2+ 2p3/2) and metallic Ni (Ni0 2p3/2) on the catalyst surface respectively, and the binding energies of 860 eV is attributed to Ni2+ satellite peak (Fig. 7 a). When the pyrolysis temperature is 300 °C, the organic complex has not begun to decompose, most Ni species still exist in the form of Ni2+, and the catalyst shows poor activity. When the pyrolysis temperature continues to increases, the signal peak intensity of Ni2+ gradually decreases, and the signal peak intensity of Ni0 gradually increases, which is consistent with the results of XRD and TG analysis. Table 2 lists the contents of the various Ni species on the surface of each catalyst. When the pyrolysis temperature is 350 °C, the ratio of Ni0/Ni2+ is 1.06, indicating that numerous Ni/NiO heterostructures are available on the Ni@C-350 catalyst surface, which may account for the excellent maleic anhydride hydrogenation performance of catalyst. The C 1s spectrum (Fig. 7b) can be deconvoluted to three distinct peaks at ∼284.8 (C–C), ∼286.8 (CO), and ∼288.7 eV (COOH) [40]. The deconvoluted O 1s spectrum (Fig. 7c) shows two distinct peaks at ∼531 and ∼537 eV attributed to O in NiO (Ni-O) and O combined with C (C-O bond), respectively [41]. The percentages of Ni, C, and O on the catalyst surface were calculated based on the XPS spectra (Table S2). With an increase in the pyrolysis temperature, the percentages of Ni and C atoms increase, and the percentage of O atoms decreases, leading to an increase in the C/O ratio. Furthermore, the C/Ni atomic ratio obtained via XPS analysis is considerably higher than that obtained via ICP (Table 2 and Table S3-S4), indicating that during the pyrolysis process, carbon species migrate to the surface of the catalyst [42]. The coating structure can act as a protection for Ni species and significantly improve the stability of the catalyst. Fig. S6 shows the SEM and EDS results obtained for the Ni@C-350 catalyst, wherein spherical particles are present along with uniformly distributed Ni, C, and O. Based on the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Fig. 8 a), the catalyst has a uniform core-shell structure (Fig.8b-c), and the metal nanoparticles are coated with a carbon layer [43,44]. The average particle size distribution in Fig. S7 shows that Ni@C-350 has the smallest Ni particle size(4.46 ± 0.02 nm) among the other catalysts. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig.8c) and HRTEM (Fig. 8d and Fig. S8) image show that the lattice spacings of the Ni (111) and NiO(111) crystal planes are 0.21 and 0.24 nm, respectively. Therefore, the coexistence of Ni and NiO species in the Ni@C-350 catalyst is confirmed, which may lead to the development of a Ni/NiO heterogeneous interface [26,44,45] (Fig. 8d and Fig.S8). During pyrolysis, the carbon species gradually migrate to the surface of the metal species and finally form a thin carbon coating on the metal nanoparticle. This could be the main reason for the excellent stability of the Ni@C-350 catalyst. H2-TPD analysis was performed to understand the adsorption, desorption, and activation properties of different catalysts toward H2 molecules. As shown in Fig. 9 , the curves can be deconvoluted into four desorption peaks, namely, Hα-82 °C, Hβ-117 °C, Hγ-160 °C, and Hδ-200 °C, in the range of 50-300 °C [46,47]. The desorption peak Hα is attributed to the desorption of hydrogen species that physically interact with the catalyst surface, whereas Hβ and Hγ peaks are attributed to the desorption of hydrogen species adsorbed on the surface of the highly dispersed nickel metal particles. The desorption peak Hδ is associated with the overflow of hydrogen generated on the carbon species on the catalyst surface. The quantitative analysis results (Table S5) show that the Ni@C-350 catalyst exhibits the highest H2 desorption (636.26 μmol/gcat), and the H2 adsorption and activation abilities of Ni@C-350 are significantly better than those of the other catalysts. The influence of Ni/NiO heterojunction on the hydrogenation of CC and hydrogenolysis of CO during MA hydrogenation was evaluated. First, the turnover frequency (TOF) of CC hydrogenation catalysed by a single Ni atom was calculated based on the analysis results of H2-TPD and the MA hydrogenation reaction at 80 °C. Furthermore, the TOF values for CO hydrogenation catalysed by a single Ni atom were calculated based on the hydrogenation of SAH to GBL at 200 °C according to Formula (4). The results are summarised in Table 1. Ni@C-350 exhibits the highest TOFCC and TOFCO, indicating that the presence of the Ni/NiO heterojunction in the Ni@C-350 catalyst significantly improves the catalytic hydrogenation activity of CC and the hydrogenolysis activity of CO. 3.3 Reaction mechanism The key to the synthesis of GBL via MA hydrogenation is the adsorption and activation of carbonyl bonds on the SAH molecules. To investigate the adsorption and activation abilities of carbonyl bonds, cyclohexanone was used as a probe molecule for in situ FT-IR investigation on the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10 , the absorption peak at 1705 cm−1 is assigned to the CO stretching vibration of the cyclohexanone molecule. No obvious peak near 1705 cm−1 is detected in the Ni@C-300 catalyst spectrum, showing that Ni@C-300 cannot adsorb and activate CO. In contrast, the characteristic absorption peaks corresponding to the stretching vibration of carbonyl groups at 1692 cm−1 is observed for the Ni@C-350 catalyst. Upon further increasing the pyrolysis temperature, the wavenumber of the carbonyl peak increases, and the peak area decreases, indicating that the highest number of available sites for the adsorption and activation of CO exists in Ni@C-350. As mentioned above, the XPS characterization results show that Ni0 and Ni2+ coexist in all samples, but the proportions are different. With the increase of heat treatment temperature, the Ni° content on the catalyst surface increases and the Ni2+ content decreases. According to the results of TG and XRD, when the pyrolysis temperature is 300 °C, only a small number of NiO species exist in the catalyst, so the catalytic activity is poor. When the pyrolysis temperature is 350 °C, the ratio of Ni0/Ni2+ is about 1, there should be more Ni/NiO heterojunction structure on catalyst surface. The Ni0/Ni2+ ratio on catalyst surface increased with the pyrolysis temperature increasing (Table S3). To more accurately compare the hydrogenation activity of individual Ni atoms on the surface of each catalyst, the TOF values of CC and CO hydrogenation catalyzed by each catalyst were calculated. The highest TOF values for CC bond hydrogenation and CO bond hydrogenolysis of Ni@C-350 indicates that there are extra active sites (bisedes Ni) on it's surface for adsorption and activation of CC and CO bonds. We think that the Ni/NiO heterojunction structures may play a vital role in the catalyst active center mentioned above. Combined with the previous research work, Song et al. [24], Singh et al. [48], and Chen et al [49]. calculated the adsorption energies of H2, H atoms, and carbonyl compounds on Ni (111) and NiO (111) surfaces using density functional theory. The calculation results showed that Ni0 is the main active site for the adsorption and activation of H2 molecules, whereas the NiO sites plausibly adsorb compounds containing CO bonds and interact with them to weaken the CO bonds [44,50]. Therefore, NiO in the Ni/NiO heterojunction plays a vital role in the adsorption and activation of CO bonds. Based on the aforementioned analysis, abundant Ni/NiO heterojunctions are formed on the surface of the Ni@C-350 catalyst, which is the key to its high catalytic activity in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of MA. As shown in Fig. S9, H2-TPR confirmed the stability of Ni@C-350 catalyst, and the hydrogen consumption amount of the catalyst before (33.37 mmol/gcat) and after (30.61 mmol/gcat) the reaction was basically the same, which further demonstrated the catalyst is not reduced in liquid phase reaction conditions. As per the literature, Ni0 is the main adsorption and activation site for H2 to generate active hydrogen free radicals via homolysis. Active hydrogen free radicals are prone to migration to NiO sites owing to their thermodynamic instability. Therefore, the following reaction mechanism is proposed for the hydrogenation of MA to GBL on Ni@C-350 (Fig. 11 ): (1) H2 is adsorbed at the Ni0 site and dissociates into two active hydrogen radicals. (2) Combined with the aforementioned kinetic results, MA molecules are adsorbed to the surface of the catalyst and quickly converted into SAH. (3) SAH molecules are adsorbed near the NiO site because Ni2+ with a certain degree electron deficiency acts as a Lewis acid. Therefore, NiO acts as an additional adsorption site for SAH to adsorb and activate CO bonds, facilitating the hydrogenation of unsaturated bonds with hydrogen radicals from adjacent Ni0 sites to form GBL, thus achieving high GBL selectivity. 4 Conclusions A hydrothermal carbonisation approach was used in this study to prepare core-shell Ni@C catalysts. Multiple characterisations and kinetic investigations were combined to elucidate the structure-activity relationship of the catalysts. Among the analysed catalysts, Ni@C-350 exhibited the highest H2 adsorption and activation capacity. Additionally, a considerable number of Ni/NiO heterojunctions were formed on the catalyst surface, and the Ni0 and Ni2+ sites exhibited synergistic effects in the liquid phase hydrogenation of MA to GBL. Under mild conditions, the catalyst achieved 100 % MA conversion and 99.89 % GBL selectivity. Based on the cycle evaluation results, the Ni@C-350 catalyst exhibits high stability and significant potential for industrial applications. This study offers a new perspective toward the design and construction of stable and effective non-noble metal catalysts for the hydrogenation of MA to produce GBL, which will be contribute to the biomass energy chemicals replace traditional petrochemical based energy chemicals, and make a great contribution to the energy transformation of the international community. coredata.dc:description: Core-shell Ni@C catalysts with a uniform grain size distribution were synthesised via a simple hydrothermal method followed by pyrolysis carbonisation, and their catalytic performance for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride (MA) was investigated herein. When the pyrolysis temperature was 350 °C, the resulting Ni@C catalyst (Ni@C-350) possessed abundant Ni/NiO heterostructures and a carbon surface layer. Among the analysed catalysts, Ni@C-350 demonstrated the lowest apparent activation energy for the hydrogenation of CC bonds (Ea = 34.3 KJ/mol) and CO bonds (Ea = 65.18 KJ/mol), yielding an MA conversion of 100 % and a γ-butyrolactone (GBL) selectivity of 99.89 % under mild reaction conditions (200 °C, 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, and 0.05 g catalyst). Furthermore, the Ni@C-350 catalyst exhibited high stability, with the yield of GBL above 95 % after five consecutive usage cycles. Ni@C-350 significantly outperformed other previously reported catalysts for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of MA.
coredata.dc:title: Ni@C nanocatalysts for the highly efficient hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to γ-butyrolactone
